contentrichtext.text: {{BLP sources|date=February 2010}} '''Helen Atkinson-Wood''' (born 14 March 1955) is an English actress and comedian born in [[Cheadle Hulme]], [[Metropolitan Borough of Stockport|Stockport]], [[Cheshire]]. Atkinson-Wood studied [[fine art]] at the [[Ruskin School]], Oxford University, where she performed with [[Rowan Atkinson]]. She also performed at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] Festival, where she met [[Ben Elton]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} ==Biography== Atkinson-Wood was a regular presenter of [[Central Television]]'s controversial ''[[O.T.T.]]'' and had a cameo in the 1984 ''[[The Young Ones (TV series)|Young Ones]]'' episode "Nasty".<ref>{{IMDb name|id=0040814|name=Helen Atkinson-Wood}}</ref> She is well known for her role as [[Mrs Miggins]] in ''[[Blackadder the Third]]'' (co-written by [[Ben Elton]] and [[Richard Curtis]]). She was the only woman on comedy programme ''[[Radio Active (radio series)|Radio Active]]'', where she played Anna Daptor and other roles, and participated in the televisual equivalent of ''Radio Active'', ''[[KYTV (TV series)|KYTV]]''. She also appeared in the final episode of ''[[Joking Apart]]'' as a morning television presenter. In 2007, she guest-starred in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' audio play ''[[I.D. (Doctor Who audio)|I.D.]]''. She played the role of [[Sam Vimes#Lady Sybil|Sybil Ramkin]] in a BBC radio adaptation of ''[[Guards! Guards!]]'' by [[Terry Pratchett]]. She has been a regular presenter for the [[Channel 4]] series ''[[Collector's Lot]]''. She has made guest appearances on programmes such as ''[[Call My Bluff (US game show)|Call My Bluff]]''. She was a guest in episode 9 of the C series of [[QI]], answering a question deemed impossible by host [[Stephen Fry]] by correctly naming a chemical reaction equation as an explosion in custard, earning 200 points. [[Craig Ferguson]] wrote in his book ''[[American on Purpose]]'' that he and Helen Atkinson-Wood were in a romantic relationship that lasted five years.
